Subject: Day 1: Storage Engines (LSM Trees)
Description: THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 3. Focus on SSTables, Memtables, and Log-Structured storage. LAB: Write a script in Go/Python that appends Key-Values to a log file (Write Ahead Log) and reads them back.

Subject: Day 2: Memtable Implementation
Description: THEORY: Understand Red-Black Trees vs Skip Lists for in-memory storage. LAB: Implement an in-memory Memtable (using a TreeMap) that flushes to disk as an immutable SSTable when full.

Subject: Day 3: Bloom Filters
Description: THEORY: Study Probabilistic Data Structures. Understand why they never return False Negatives. LAB: Implement a Bloom Filter from scratch using MurmurHash. Prove false positives exist.

Subject: Day 4: Compaction Strategies
Description: THEORY: Compare Size-Tiered vs Leveled Compaction (used in Cassandra/LevelDB). LAB: Write a background script that merges two sorted SSTable files into one new file (Merge Sort).

Subject: Day 5: Deep Dive - BigTable
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 3 (GFS). READ: The Google BigTable Paper. ANALYSIS: Connect the dots between GFS (File System) and BigTable (KV Store).

Subject: Day 6: Code Review - LevelDB
Description: TASK: Clone the LevelDB or BadgerDB (Go) repository. Trace the 'Put' and 'Get' functions in the source code to see how they handle concurrency.

Subject: Day 7: Encoding & Evolution
Description: THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 4. Understand Avro/Protobuf vs JSON. LAB: Define an Avro schema. Write code to 'evolve' it (add a field) and verify old code can still read the new data.

Subject: Day 8: B-Trees (Mutable Indexing)
Description: THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 3 (B-Trees section). Understand Branching Factors and Depth. LAB: Use 'strace' on a SQLite process to watch 4KB pages being read from disk.

Subject: Day 9: Page Structures
Description: THEORY: Deep dive into Slotted Pages and Free Lists. LAB: Implement a basic B-Tree Node class in code that can hold keys and child pointers (do not implement balancing yet).

Subject: Day 10: Crash Recovery (WAL)
Description: THEORY: Write-Ahead Logs (WAL) and Checkpoints. ARIES algorithm basics. LAB: Implement a 'Recover' function that reads your WAL file and reconstructs the Memtable after a 'crash'.

Subject: Day 11: Columnar Storage
Description: THEORY: Read about Parquet and Clickhouse. Understand Column-oriented vs Row-oriented storage. LAB: Convert a CSV file to a Binary Columnar format. Compare file size/compression.

Subject: Day 12: Deep Dive - Dremel
Description: READ: Google's Dremel Paper (The basis of BigQuery). Focus on how they handle Nested Data structures efficiently.

Subject: Day 13: Benchmark Day
Description: LAB: Write a benchmark suite. Generate 1 million keys. Compare Random Write performance on your LSM Code vs your B-Tree Code. Observe the write amplification.

Subject: Day 14: Infrastructure as Code (IaC)
Description: THEORY: Declarative vs Imperative infrastructure. LAB: Write a Terraform script to provision a local Docker container or a free-tier AWS EC2 instance.

Subject: Day 15: Transactions (ACID)
Description: THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 7. Define Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability. LAB: Write a test script that proves MongoDB single-document ACID compliance.

Subject: Day 16: Isolation Levels
Description: THEORY: Understand Read Committed vs Repeatable Read. LAB: Open two Postgres terminals. demonstrate 'Dirty Write' and 'Lost Update' phenomena manually.

Subject: Day 17: Snapshot Isolation (MVCC)
Description: THEORY: Multi-Version Concurrency Control. LAB: Inspect Postgres 'xmin' and 'xmax' system columns during a transaction to see how it stores multiple versions.

Subject: Day 18: Serializability
Description: THEORY: 2PL (Two-Phase Locking) vs SSI (Serializable Snapshot Isolation). LAB: Simulate a Deadlock in SQL using explicit locking commands.

Subject: Day 19: Distributed Transactions
Description: THEORY: Two-Phase Commit (2PC) vs Sagas. LAB: Implement a basic 2PC Coordinator between two mock microservices (Order Service and Payment Service).

Subject: Day 20: Deep Dive - Spanner
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 13 (Spanner). READ: Google's Spanner Paper. Understand TrueTime, Atomic Clocks, and External Consistency.

Subject: Day 21: Batch Processing
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 1 (Introduction/MapReduce). THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 10. LAB: Write a Python script mimicking Map and Reduce phases on a 1GB text file.

Subject: Day 22: Network Internals
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 2 (RPC & Threads). LAB: Wireshark Deep Dive. Capture packets and analyze the TCP Handshake and HTTPS Overhead.

Subject: Day 23: OS I/O Internals
Description: THEORY: Standard I/O vs mmap vs O_DIRECT. Page Cache. LAB: Benchmark reading a 1GB file using standard read() vs mmap(). Explain the difference.

Subject: Day 24: I/O Multiplexing
Description: THEORY: blocking I/O vs select vs poll vs epoll. LAB: Write a basic TCP server using the 'epoll' system call (or your language's async equivalent).

Subject: Day 25: HTTP Protocols
Description: THEORY: HTTP/1.1 vs HTTP/2 (Multiplexing) vs HTTP/3 (QUIC/UDP). LAB: Load test an HTTP/2 server. Observe how multiple requests share one connection.

Subject: Day 26: Load Balancing
Description: THEORY: L4 vs L7 Load Balancing. Algorithms (Round Robin, Least Conn). LAB: Implement 'Weighted Round Robin' algorithm in Python/Go code.

Subject: Day 27: Deep Dive - NGINX
Description: READ: NGINX Architecture Overview. Understand the Event Loop model vs Apache's Thread-per-request model.

Subject: Day 28: Month 1 Review
Description: REVIEW: Re-read DDIA Ch 3 & 7 highlights. Organize your notes. Ensure your DB engine code compiles and runs.

Subject: Day 29: Replication
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 4 (Primary-Backup). THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 5. LAB: Setup MySQL Replication. Kill the master. Promote slave manually.

Subject: Day 30: Replication Lag
Description: THEORY: Statement-based vs Row-based logs. Problems with Lag. LAB: Measure replication lag time under heavy write load (insert 10k rows).

Subject: Day 31: Quorums
Description: THEORY: R + W > N. Consistency levels. LAB: Write a script to simulate Quorum reads/writes with node failures. Calculate probability of stale reads.

Subject: Day 32: Consistency Models
Description: THEORY: Linearizability vs Eventual Consistency. LAB: Read Jepsen.io analysis of MongoDB or Cassandra. Understand how they lose data.

Subject: Day 33: Logical Clocks
Description: THEORY: Physical vs Logical Clocks. Lamport Clocks vs Vector Clocks. LAB: Implement Vector Clocks code to detect concurrent updates in a distributed list.

Subject: Day 34: Deep Dive - Dynamo
Description: READ: Amazon's Dynamo Paper. Focus on the 'Shopping Cart' use case, Ring Hashing, and Vector Clocks.

Subject: Day 35: Security Deep Dive
Description: THEORY: OWASP Top 10. XSS, CSRF, SQLi. LAB: Perform a SQL Injection on your local DB, then patch it using Prepared Statements.

Subject: Day 36: Partitioning (Sharding)
Description: THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 6. Key-Range vs Hash Partitioning. LAB: Manually shard a SQLite DB across 3 files based on UserID.

Subject: Day 37: Consistent Hashing
Description: THEORY: The Hash Ring & Virtual Nodes. LAB: Code a Consistent Hash Ring. Add a node and programmatically count how many keys needed to move.

Subject: Day 38: Rebalancing
Description: THEORY: Dynamic Partitioning strategies. LAB: Simulate the 'Justin Bieber' (Hot Partition/Skew) problem in your hashing code.

Subject: Day 39: Gossip Protocols
Description: THEORY: SWIM Protocol / Request Routing. Failure Detection. LAB: Implement a basic heartbeat/ping check between 3 nodes.

Subject: Day 40: Deep Dive - Ringpop
Description: READ: Uber's 'Ringpop' blog post. Understand application-layer sharding and member lists.

Subject: Day 41: Lab: Sharded KV Store
Description: TASK: Combine your Month 1 DB Engine + Month 2 Consistent Hashing logic to make a distributed Key-Value store.

Subject: Day 42: CDN Internals
Description: THEORY: Anycast IP, PoPs, Cache Invalidation Patterns. LAB: Setup Cloudflare (Free) for a static site and inspect headers.

Subject: Day 43: Byzantine Generals
Description: THEORY: The Two Generals Problem. Understand why 100% Consensus is mathematically impossible in asynchronous networks.

Subject: Day 44: Paxos Basics
Description: THEORY: Paxos Phases (Prepare/Promise, Propose/Accept). Don't code yet, just understand the Proposer/Acceptor roles.

Subject: Day 45: Raft (Leader Election)
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 6 (Raft I). LAB: Use the Raft Visualization tool online. Understand Random Timeouts.

Subject: Day 46: Raft (Log Replication)
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 7 (Raft II). THEORY: The Replicated Log. LAB: Define the Structs/Classes needed for a Raft Node (Term, Log, Index).

Subject: Day 47: Lab - Build Raft (Part 1)
Description: TASK: Implement the 'Leader Election' ticker and voting logic in Go/Python. Nodes should vote for a candidate.

Subject: Day 48: Lab - Build Raft (Part 2)
Description: TASK: Implement the 'AppendEntries' RPC to replicate logs from Leader to Followers. Handle the heartbeat.

Subject: Day 49: Raft Edge Cases
Description: THEORY: Split Votes & Network Partitions. TASK: Test your Raft implementation by simulating a network partition (drop packets).

Subject: Day 50: ZooKeeper/Etcd
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 8 (ZooKeeper). THEORY: Atomic Broadcast (ZAB). LAB: Run Etcd. Use 'etcdctl' to set keys and watch changes.

Subject: Day 51: Distributed Locks
Description: THEORY: The Redlock Algorithm. LAB: Implement a Distributed Lock using Redis (Set NX PX) with a TTL.

Subject: Day 52: Leader Election (Applied)
Description: THEORY: Using ZK/Etcd for election. LAB: Write 2 Node apps that compete to become 'Active' using the Distributed Lock you built.

Subject: Day 53: Service Discovery
Description: THEORY: Client-side vs Server-side discovery. DNS vs Registry. LAB: Register your mock services into Consul or Etcd.

Subject: Day 54: Deep Dive - Chubby
Description: READ: Google's Chubby Paper. Understand Coarse-grained locking and how it differs from ZooKeeper.

Subject: Day 55: Month 2 Review
Description: REVIEW: Review DDIA Ch 5, 6, 9. Review your Raft code. Ensure you understand why Split Brain happens.

Subject: Day 56: Formal Verification
Description: THEORY: TLA+ Basics. Watch Leslie Lamport's Intro. LAB: Write a simple spec for a bank transfer to see race conditions mathematically.

Subject: Day 57: Caching Patterns
Description: THEORY: Cache-Aside, Write-Through, Thundering Herd. LAB: Implement 'Request Collapsing' middleware to prevent Thundering Herd.

Subject: Day 58: Kafka Internals
Description: THEORY: Topics, Partitions, Offsets, Segments. LAB: Inspect Kafka data files on disk. Identify the .log and .index files.

Subject: Day 59: Consumer Patterns
Description: THEORY: Consumer Groups & Rebalancing protocol. LAB: Start 1 producer, 3 consumers. Kill one consumer, watch the rebalance triggers.

Subject: Day 60: Message Delivery
Description: THEORY: At-most-once vs At-least-once. LAB: Write a consumer that crashes before committing the offset. Observe duplicate processing.

Subject: Day 61: Lab - Exactly Once
Description: TASK: Build a payment processor using Kafka Transactions (read-process-write atomic). Understand the 'fencing zombie' problem.

Subject: Day 62: Deep Dive - LinkedIn Logs
Description: READ: LinkedIn 'Log Structured Streaming' blog. Understand why the Log is the heart of data infrastructure.

Subject: Day 63: Stream Processing
Description: THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 11. Time Windows (Tumbling vs Sliding). LAB: Implement a Sliding Window counter (e.g., requests in last 5 mins).

Subject: Day 64: Kubernetes Architecture
Description: THEORY: API Server, Etcd, Controller Manager, Scheduler. LAB: 'Kubernetes the Hard Way' (Do the Control Plane setup step).

Subject: Day 65: Service Mesh
Description: THEORY: The Sidecar Pattern (Envoy/Istio). LAB: Install Istio. Visualize traffic graph between 2 pods using Kiali/Jaeger.

Subject: Day 66: Circuit Breakers
Description: THEORY: Fail Fast to prevent cascading failure. LAB: Implement a Circuit Breaker in code. Test it with a failing backend service.

Subject: Day 67: API Gateways
Description: THEORY: BFF Pattern, Rate Limiting, TLS Termination. LAB: Configure Nginx as a Gateway performing Rate Limiting.

Subject: Day 68: Deep Dive - Borg
Description: READ: Google's Borg Paper. Compare the 'Alloc' concept to Kubernetes Pods.

Subject: Day 69: Lab - K8s Operator
Description: TASK: Write a simple custom Kubernetes Controller in Go/Python that monitors a ConfigMap and updates a Deployment.

Subject: Day 70: Formal Verification (Cloud)
Description: THEORY: How AWS proves network correctness (Zelkova). Read AWS automated reasoning blog.

Subject: Day 71: Tracing
Description: THEORY: Distributed Context Propagation (TraceID/SpanID). LAB: Instrument an app with Jaeger/OpenTelemetry.

Subject: Day 72: Metrics
Description: THEORY: Prometheus (Pull model) vs Push model. LAB: Expose custom metrics (/metrics endpoint) and scrape them with Prometheus.

Subject: Day 73: Logging
Description: THEORY: Structured Logging (JSON) vs Text. ELK Stack. LAB: Setup Fluentd to ship logs from Docker to a file or Elasticsearch.

Subject: Day 74: Auth Deep Dive
Description: THEORY: OAuth2 flows (Auth Code vs Client Creds). OIDC. LAB: Manually construct an OAuth2 request to Google/GitHub.

Subject: Day 75: mTLS & Zero Trust
Description: THEORY: Mutual TLS (Two-way authentication). LAB: Generate CA certificates and configure 2-way SSL between two microservices.

Subject: Day 76: Lab - Observability Dashboard
Description: TASK: Build a Grafana Dashboard showing 95th percentile latency and Error Rates for your test app.

Subject: Day 77: Chaos Engineering
Description: THEORY: Netflix Chaos Monkey. LAB: Write a script that randomly kills your Docker containers. Ensure the system recovers.

Subject: Day 78: Big Data (Batch - Spark)
Description: WATCH: MIT 6.824 Lecture 15 (Spark). THEORY: Read DDIA Chapter 10. RDDs. LAB: Write a Spark job to process a large CSV.

Subject: Day 79: Lambda vs Kappa
Description: THEORY: Architecture Patterns. Lambda (Speed+Batch) vs Kappa (Stream only). LAB: Draw the architecture for a system needing both Real-time and Historical views.

Subject: Day 80: Vector Databases
Description: THEORY: Embeddings & HNSW Index. LAB: Use OpenAI API to get text embeddings, store them in Pinecone/Milvus.

Subject: Day 81: Lab - Semantic Search
Description: TASK: Build a search bar that finds documents based on 'meaning', not keywords, using your Vector DB.

Subject: Day 82: Data Warehousing
Description: THEORY: Snowflake Architecture (Separation of Compute/Storage). Star Schema vs Snowflake Schema.

Subject: Day 83: Deep Dive - MapReduce
Description: READ: Google's MapReduce Paper. Understand the Shuffle/Sort phase details.

Subject: Day 84: Month 3 Review
Description: REVIEW: Review Cloud patterns, Kafka internals, and Observability tools.

Subject: Day 85: Design Typeahead
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2. FOCUS: Tries, Prefix search, Top-k caching. Handling trending searches.

Subject: Day 86: Design Web Crawler
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 1. FOCUS: URL Frontier, Politeness, DNS resolution, Robot.txt handling.

Subject: Day 87: Design Dist Scheduler
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2. FOCUS: Cron at scale, Leader election for scheduler, Etcd usage.

Subject: Day 88: Design Ad Aggregator
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2. FOCUS: Stream processing, Lambda Architecture, Exactly-once counting.

Subject: Day 89: Design Collab Editor
Description: SOURCE: Google Docs logic. FOCUS: Operational Transformation (OT) vs CRDTs. LAB: Build a simple CRDT counter in JS.

Subject: Day 90: Design Geo-Spatial
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2 (Uber/Yelp). FOCUS: QuadTrees vs Geohashes. LAB: Play with Redis GEO commands.

Subject: Day 91: Design Digital Wallet
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2. FOCUS: Double-entry ledger, Distributed Transactions, Sagas, Idempotency.

Subject: Day 92: Design Twitter
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 1. FOCUS: Fan-out on Write vs Fan-out on Read. Hybrid approach for celebrities.

Subject: Day 93: Design WhatsApp
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 1. FOCUS: End-to-End Encryption, WebSocket handling, Push Notifications.

Subject: Day 94: Design Netflix
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 1. FOCUS: CDN Design, Adaptive Bitrate Streaming, Pre-computing videos.

Subject: Day 95: Design Google Drive
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 1. FOCUS: Block-level splitting, Hashing for Deduplication, Sync conflict resolution.

Subject: Day 96: Design Payment Gateway
Description: SOURCE: Stripe Clone. FOCUS: Idempotency keys, Reliability, Reconciliation jobs.

Subject: Day 97: Design Stock Exchange
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2. FOCUS: Matching Engine (FIFO), Ultra-low latency, Multicast for market data.

Subject: Day 98: Design Hotel Booking
Description: SOURCE: Alex Xu Vol 2. FOCUS: Concurrency. Handling Overbooking. Optimistic vs Pessimistic Locking.

Subject: Day 99: Mock Interview 1
Description: TOPIC: Top K Leaderboard (Gaming). TASK: Record yourself explaining the design for 45 mins. Review the video.

Subject: Day 100: Mock Interview 2
Description: TOPIC: Ticketmaster (Booking). TASK: Record yourself. Focus on the locking mechanism for tickets.

Subject: Day 101: Mock Interview 3
Description: TOPIC: TinyURL (Unique IDs). TASK: Record yourself. Focus on Base62 encoding and ID generation.

Subject: Day 102: Mock Interview 4
Description: TOPIC: Notification Service. TASK: Record yourself. Focus on Queue workers and rate limiting.

Subject: Day 103: Mock Interview 5
Description: TOPIC: Rate Limiter. TASK: Record yourself. Focus on Token Bucket algorithm implementation.

Subject: Day 104: Mock Interview 6
Description: TOPIC: Instagram. TASK: Record yourself. Focus on Feed generation and Image storage.

Subject: Day 105: Mock Interview 7
Description: TOPIC: Parking Garage. TASK: Record yourself. Focus on Object-Oriented Design + System limits.

Subject: Day 106: Capstone 1 - Crypto Exchange
Description: TASK: Design a Global Crypto Exchange. Create a 5-page Architecture Doc. Handle Race conditions & Ledger integrity.

Subject: Day 107: Capstone 1 - Work
Description: TASK: Define the API Spec (gRPC) and Database Schema (SQL). Draw the component diagram.

Subject: Day 108: Capstone 1 - Review
Description: TASK: Self-Audit. What happens if the Matching Engine crashes? How do you recover state?

Subject: Day 109: Capstone 2 - Zoom Competitor
Description: TASK: Design a Video Conference system. Focus on UDP vs TCP, WebRTC, and Media Servers.

Subject: Day 110: Capstone 2 - Work
Description: TASK: Define Signaling Server logic and Data center selection logic. Draw the diagram.

Subject: Day 111: Capstone 2 - Review
Description: TASK: Self-Audit. How do you handle packet loss? How does the system scale to 1000 users?

Subject: Day 112: The Future of Data
Description: READ: DDIA Chapter 12. Data Integration & Unbundling Databases. The Unix philosophy applied to data.

Subject: Day 113: Review Weakness
Description: FOCUS: Revisit Raft or Consensus if you are shaky. Re-watch MIT Lecture 6/7 if needed.

Subject: Day 114: Review Weakness
Description: FOCUS: Revisit DB Internals (LSM vs B-Tree). Ensure you can explain write amplification.

Subject: Day 115: Review Weakness
Description: FOCUS: Revisit K8s/Cloud patterns. Ensure you understand Sidecars and Ingress.

Subject: Day 116: Final Polish
Description: TASK: Review Design Interview cheat sheets. Memorize Latency numbers (RAM vs Disk vs Network).

Subject: Day 117: Final Polish
Description: TASK: Re-read your notes from Month 1. Trace the journey from a single log file to a distributed database.

Subject: Day 118: Final Polish
Description: TASK: Mental Prep. Visualize a successful design interview. Draw one final system just for fun.

Subject: Day 119: Rest
Description: TASK: Do absolutely nothing. Sleep. Let the knowledge settle.

Subject: Day 120: MASTERY ACHIEVED
Description: STATUS: You are now a Principal Engineer level architect. Congratulations.
